channel.title: Data Analysis on Moritz Mueller-Navarra
channel.description: Recent content in Data Analysis on Moritz Mueller-Navarra

item.title: Sales forecasting with fable
item.description:
Hi, in this post I will analyze sales data. The data comes from https://www.kaggle.com and was made public by https://www.olist.com. Olist is a company which owns department stores in brazil. The data was generated through the online store of Olist. Merchants all over Brazil are connected to Olist. When someone purchases an item from the Olist Store, the merchant gets notified to fulfill that order.

The main objective of this analysis is to analyze sales time series and forecast future sales. We will use

  • data.table
  • dplyr
  • plotly
  • fable & feasts
  • tsibble

fable is a new package, which uses a tidy approach to forecasting time series. It is a new approach for time series analysis & forecasting from the developers of the forecast package. feasts will be used for plotting, whereas tsibble provides the data structure on which fable functions operate. feasts also produces time series features, decompositions, statistical summaries and visualisations.

Packages

You can install fable and feasts with the following commands.

devtools::install_github(repo = "tidyverts/fable")
devtools::install_github("tidyverts/feasts")
library("data.table")
library("dplyr")
library("plotly")
library("fable")
library("feasts")
library("tsibble")

After we loaded the packages, we start by downloading the data.

Data

You find the data here: https://www.kaggle.com/olistbr/brazilian-ecommerce

I downloaded the data to a local directory. Afterwards I generate a list and save the data as a list element in all_data.

#reading the data
file_path <- list.files(path = file.path("D:","data", "toy"), full.names = TRUE)
all_data <- lapply(file_path, function(x){
  data.table::fread(x)
})
#renaming list elements to meaningful names
file_name <- basename(file_path)
all_data  <- setNames(all_data, gsub(".csv", "", x = file_name))
names(all_data)
##  [1] "olist_closed_deals_dataset"             
##  [2] "olist_customers_dataset"                
##  [3] "olist_geolocation_dataset"              
##  [4] "olist_marketing_qualified_leads_dataset"
##  [5] "olist_order_items_dataset"              
##  [6] "olist_order_payments_dataset"           
##  [7] "olist_order_reviews_dataset"            
##  [8] "olist_orders_dataset"                   
##  [9] "olist_products_dataset"                 
## [10] "olist_sellers_dataset"                  
## [11] "product_category_name_translation"

Joining the data

As I want to analyze the data set based on product category, I now join relevant list elements into one table. We start by joining olist_order_customer_dataset to olist_orders_dataset. We use customer_id as the join column.

customer_orders <- all_data[["olist_customers_dataset"]][all_data[["olist_orders_dataset"]], on = "customer_id"]

Next we can join our new table to olist_order_items_dataset based on order_id.

customer_orders <- customer_orders[all_data[["olist_order_items_dataset"]], on = "order_id"]

Here is an example of a specific order_id. We see that the customer ordered the same item three times. Since an order_id contains all items ordered by a customer, we can simply sum the price and/or quantity for day, week, month. This results in a time series, which we can analyze and forecast.

customer_orders[order_id == "00143d0f86d6fbd9f9b38ab440ac16f5"]
##                         customer_id               customer_unique_id
## 1: 2e45292979b9b2700ea09560eeb0f803 bb8a37225e0279ac8a274c9765617eaf
## 2: 2e45292979b9b2700ea09560eeb0f803 bb8a37225e0279ac8a274c9765617eaf
## 3: 2e45292979b9b2700ea09560eeb0f803 bb8a37225e0279ac8a274c9765617eaf
##    customer_zip_code_prefix customer_city customer_state
## 1:                    74663       goiania             GO
## 2:                    74663       goiania             GO
## 3:                    74663       goiania             GO
##                            order_id order_status order_purchase_timestamp
## 1: 00143d0f86d6fbd9f9b38ab440ac16f5    delivered      2017-10-16 15:29:43
## 2: 00143d0f86d6fbd9f9b38ab440ac16f5    delivered      2017-10-16 15:29:43
## 3: 00143d0f86d6fbd9f9b38ab440ac16f5    delivered      2017-10-16 15:29:43
##      order_approved_at order_delivered_carrier_date
## 1: 2017-10-16 16:07:52          2017-10-16 23:04:43
## 2: 2017-10-16 16:07:52          2017-10-16 23:04:43
## 3: 2017-10-16 16:07:52          2017-10-16 23:04:43
##    order_delivered_customer_date order_estimated_delivery_date
## 1:           2017-10-27 18:43:56           2017-11-06 00:00:00
## 2:           2017-10-27 18:43:56           2017-11-06 00:00:00
## 3:           2017-10-27 18:43:56           2017-11-06 00:00:00
##    order_item_id                       product_id
## 1:             1 e95ee6822b66ac6058e2e4aff656071a
## 2:             2 e95ee6822b66ac6058e2e4aff656071a
## 3:             3 e95ee6822b66ac6058e2e4aff656071a
##                           seller_id shipping_limit_date price
## 1: a17f621c590ea0fab3d5d883e1630ec6 2017-10-20 16:07:52 21.33
## 2: a17f621c590ea0fab3d5d883e1630ec6 2017-10-20 16:07:52 21.33
## 3: a17f621c590ea0fab3d5d883e1630ec6 2017-10-20 16:07:52 21.33
##    freight_value
## 1:          15.1
## 2:          15.1
## 3:          15.1

Now we join the product category to the data, since we want to analyze the sales per product_caegory.

customer_orders <- all_data[["olist_products_dataset"]][customer_orders, on = "product_id"]

Joining the translated categories to customer_orders, we get

customer_orders <- all_data[["product_category_name_translation"]][customer_orders, on = "product_category_name"]
#dropping the product_category_name_column
customer_orders[, product_category_name := NULL]
setnames(customer_orders, "product_category_name_english", "product_category")
customer_orders[, product_category := as.factor(product_category)]
customer_orders[, .(product_category = unique(product_category))]
##                            product_category
##  1:                              cool_stuff
##  2:                                pet_shop
##  3:                         furniture_decor
##  4:                               perfumery
##  5:                            garden_tools
##  6:                              housewares
##  7:                               telephony
##  8:                           health_beauty
##  9:                         books_technical
## 10:                fashion_bags_accessories
## 11:                          bed_bath_table
## 12:                          sports_leisure
## 13:                          consoles_games
## 14:                        office_furniture
## 15:                     luggage_accessories
## 16:                                    food
## 17:              agro_industry_and_commerce
## 18:                             electronics
## 19:                   computers_accessories
## 20:         construction_tools_construction
## 21:                                   audio
## 22:                                    baby
## 23:               construction_tools_lights
## 24:                                    toys
## 25:                              stationery
## 26:          industry_commerce_and_business
## 27:                           watches_gifts
## 28:                                    auto
## 29:                                    <NA>
## 30:                         home_appliances
## 31: kitchen_dining_laundry_garden_furniture
## 32:                        air_conditioning
## 33:                            home_confort
## 34:                         fixed_telephony
## 35:   small_appliances_home_oven_and_coffee
## 36:                     diapers_and_hygiene
## 37:                  signaling_and_security
## 38:                     musical_instruments
## 39:                        small_appliances
## 40:                costruction_tools_garden
## 41:                                     art
## 42:                       home_construction
## 43:                  books_general_interest
## 44:                          party_supplies
## 45:               construction_tools_safety
## 46:                              cine_photo
## 47:                 fashion_underwear_beach
## 48:                   fashion_male_clothing
## 49:                              food_drink
## 50:                                  drinks
## 51:                   furniture_living_room
## 52:                            market_place
## 53:                                   music
## 54:                           fashion_shoes
## 55:                                 flowers
## 56:                       home_appliances_2
## 57:                  fashio_female_clothing
## 58:                               computers
## 59:                          books_imported
## 60:                      christmas_supplies
## 61:                       furniture_bedroom
## 62:                          home_comfort_2
## 63:                            dvds_blu_ray
## 64:                       cds_dvds_musicals
## 65:                   arts_and_craftmanship
## 66:       furniture_mattress_and_upholstery
## 67:                  tablets_printing_image
## 68:                 costruction_tools_tools
## 69:                           fashion_sport
## 70:                              la_cuisine
## 71:                   security_and_services
## 72:               fashion_childrens_clothes
##                            product_category

We get 72 different categories with one being NA. We set the NA category to other.

customer_orders[is.na(product_category), product_category := "other"]

The next chapter contains the time series analysis.

Time Series

Introducing new columns order_date & year as this allows us to compute sums per day & year. I will introduce weekly and monthly time stamps later.

customer_orders[, order_date := as.IDate(order_purchase_timestamp)]
customer_orders[, year := year(order_date)]

We focus on data where the order month is < 2018-09, since we only have a few observations for this month.

customer_orders <- customer_orders[tsibble::yearmonth(order_date) < tsibble::yearmonth("2018-09")]

We will also filter out the sales generated in the year 2016, since we only sold items on 13 distinct days.

customer_orders[, .(unique_days = length(unique(order_date))), by = "year"]
##    year unique_days
## 1: 2017         361
## 2: 2018         241
## 3: 2016          13
customer_orders <- customer_orders[year > 2016]

Furthermore some orders were canceled by the customer. We exclude these orders by subsetting customer_orders

customer_orders <- customer_orders[order_status != "canceled"]

How much did we sell?

As a first visual accessment of our sales, we compute sums over all years by product_category .

sales_summary <- customer_orders[, .(sum_price = sum(price)), by = c("product_category")]
setorder(sales_summary, sum_price)
#relevelling the factor levels for ordered plotting 
re_level <- sales_summary[, unique(product_category)]
sales_summary[, product_category := factor(product_category, levels = re_level)]
sales_summary %>% plot_ly() %>%
  add_bars(x = ~product_category, y = ~sum_price) %>%
  layout(title = "Total sales per product category",
         xaxis = list(title = ""))

We can also compute yearly sums independent of the product category.

 customer_orders[, .(sum_sales = sum(price)), by = c("year")] %>% plot_ly() %>%
  add_bars(x = ~factor(year), y = ~sum_sales) %>%
  layout(title = "Total sales per year", 
         xaxis = list(title = "Year"))

Since we do not have equal number of days per year, we need to normalize the sums.

We simply divide by the number of observed days in a year, thus getting average daily sales per year.

customer_orders[, .(mean_sales_day = sum(price)/length(unique(order_date))), 
                                  by = c("year")] %>%
  plot_ly() %>%
  add_bars(x = ~factor(year), y = ~mean_sales_day) %>%
  layout(title = "Mean sales per day", 
         xaxis = list(title = "Year"))

Daily time series

Now we compute the sum of price per day as this gives us the total sales (sales per day) on a given day and the total orders (volume per day) per product category. I introduce a new table, which is called sales_daily.

(sales_daily <- customer_orders[, .(sales_per_day = sum(price), 
                                    volume_per_day = .N), 
                                by = c("order_date", "product_category")])
##        order_date    product_category sales_per_day volume_per_day
##     1: 2017-09-13          cool_stuff       1916.77              7
##     2: 2017-04-26            pet_shop        746.44              5
##     3: 2018-01-14     furniture_decor       1397.68             21
##     4: 2018-08-08           perfumery       1013.25              9
##     5: 2017-02-04        garden_tools        449.70              3
##    ---                                                            
## 18794: 2017-03-29           perfumery         68.00              1
## 18795: 2018-02-11                baby        149.99              1
## 18796: 2017-03-15   home_construction        146.90              1
## 18797: 2017-09-25 luggage_accessories         92.00              1
## 18798: 2017-04-12 musical_instruments          4.90              1

This table allows for a distinct analysis for sales per product category. There are days where we do not observe any sales. I want to be able to analyze the whole time series on a product level, so I generate a data.table which has one column order_date with the whole sequence of dates between min and max order_date

(seqdates <- data.table("order_date" = seq(as.IDate(min(sales_daily$order_date)), 
                                           as.IDate(max(sales_daily$order_date)), 
                                           by = "days")))
##      order_date
##   1: 2017-01-05
##   2: 2017-01-06
##   3: 2017-01-07
##   4: 2017-01-08
##   5: 2017-01-09
##  ---           
## 598: 2018-08-25
## 599: 2018-08-26
## 600: 2018-08-27
## 601: 2018-08-28
## 602: 2018-08-29

Now we join sales_daily using the idea above with a cross join, not actually using the seqdate, but generating the date sequence inside the CJ (Cross Join) function.

setkey(sales_daily, product_category, order_date)
(sales_daily <- sales_daily[CJ(unique(product_category),
                               seq(as.IDate(min(order_date)), 
                                   as.IDate(max(order_date)), 
                                   by = "days"))])
##        order_date           product_category sales_per_day volume_per_day
##     1: 2017-01-05 agro_industry_and_commerce            NA             NA
##     2: 2017-01-06 agro_industry_and_commerce            NA             NA
##     3: 2017-01-07 agro_industry_and_commerce            NA             NA
##     4: 2017-01-08 agro_industry_and_commerce            NA             NA
##     5: 2017-01-09 agro_industry_and_commerce            NA             NA
##    ---                                                                   
## 43340: 2018-08-25                      other            NA             NA
## 43341: 2018-08-26                      other         59.90              1
## 43342: 2018-08-27                      other        547.79              2
## 43343: 2018-08-28                      other            NA             NA
## 43344: 2018-08-29                      other            NA             NA

We see missing values occuring for the variables. I make the assumption that we actually did not sell anything, when we observe NA. Missing values are therefor not due to some measurement error. Following this logic we set all NA to 0.

#Setting NA to 0
for (i in c("sales_per_day", "volume_per_day"))
    sales_daily[is.na(get(i)), (i):=0]

We get a time series without missing dates. Missing sales are set to 0.

Plot function

To generalize the plotting procedure, I wrote a helper function Plot_Func which takes seven arguments:

  1. data : The data set
  2. x_col : column name for the x values (i.e. order_date)
  3. y_col : column name for the y-values (i.e. sales_per_day)
  4. group_col : The grouping factor(i.e. re_level)
  5. title: Plot title
  6. x_axis : Label for x axis
  7. y_axis: Label for y axis

Please note that I pass the product category ordered by the summed sales to the group_col argument, which allows for a better comparison of the categories, since the plots share a y axis per row.

Plot_Func <- function(data, x_col, y_col, group_col, title, x_axis, y_axis) {
 
 u_q <- group_col
 s_q <- seq(1, length(u_q), by = 3) # chunks
 p   <- htmltools::tagList() #html taglist
 j   <- 0L
for(i in s_q){
  j <- j + 1L
  chunk <- u_q[i : (i + 2L)]
  plot_list <- lapply(seq_along(chunk), function(x){
  data[product_category == chunk[x]] %>%
        plot_ly(x = ~get(x_col), y = ~get(y_col)) %>%
        add_trace(name = chunk[x], type = "scatter", mode = "lines") %>%
        layout(title = title,
         xaxis = list(title = x_axis),
         yaxis = list (title = y_axis),
         legend = list(orientation = "h"))
  })
  p[[j]] <- subplot(plot_list, titleY = TRUE, shareY = TRUE)
   
}
return(p) 
}
Plot_Func(data = sales_daily, x_col = "order_date",
          y_col = "sales_per_day", group_col = re_level,
          x_axis = "Day", y_axis = "Sales in currency", title = "Sales daily")

The plots above illustrate that not all products share the same starting date. This is an issue, when we are trying to forecast sales. We will address this issue in the forecasting chapter.

Now we aggregate the sales for all product categories to get an overview of total sales.

sales_agg_day <- sales_daily[, .(sales_per_day = sum(sales_per_day), 
                                volume_per_day = sum(volume_per_day)), 
                                by = c("order_date")][, index := 1:.N]
sales_agg_day[, loess_day := fitted(loess(sales_per_day ~ index, span = 0.05))]
p1 <- sales_agg_day %>% plot_ly(x = ~order_date, y = ~sales_per_day) %>%
  add_lines(name = ~"sales_per_day") %>%
  add_lines(x = ~order_date, y= ~loess_day, name = "smoothed sales") %>%
  layout(title = "Aggregated daily sales")

p1

We observe a very high peak around 2017-24-11, which is presumably due to black friday sales. We also see a drop in sales at the end of the time series.

At the 2017-11-24 sales_per_day reach their gobal maximum. We applied a loess smoother to the data points. Variance is high because we look at sales on a daily level. In the next step we investigate weekly sales.

Weekly time series

Summing the sales per week leads to a similar observation. We observe a high peek (week 47 in 2017) and a drop from week 30-2018 to week 35-2018.

sales_daily[, order_week := tsibble::yearweek(order_date)]
(weekly_sales <- sales_daily[, .(sales_per_week = sum(sales_per_day), 
                                volume_per_week = sum(volume_per_day)), 
                            by = c("order_week", "product_category")])
##       order_week           product_category sales_per_week volume_per_week
##    1:   2017 W01 agro_industry_and_commerce           0.00               0
##    2:   2017 W02 agro_industry_and_commerce           0.00               0
##    3:   2017 W03 agro_industry_and_commerce           0.00               0
##    4:   2017 W04 agro_industry_and_commerce          43.98               2
##    5:   2017 W05 agro_industry_and_commerce          43.98               2
##   ---                                                                     
## 6260:   2018 W31                      other        1442.52              10
## 6261:   2018 W32                      other        1966.62              14
## 6262:   2018 W33                      other        1085.59              11
## 6263:   2018 W34                      other         445.78               4
## 6264:   2018 W35                      other         547.79               2
Plot_Func(data = weekly_sales, x_col = "order_week",
          y_col = "sales_per_week", group_col = re_level,
          x_axis = "sales week", y_axis = "sales per week", title = "Weekly sales")

Summing over all product categories and adding a loess smoother leads to following time series.

sales_agg_week <- weekly_sales[, .(sales_per_week = sum(sales_per_week), 
                             volume_per_week = sum(volume_per_week)), 
                                by = c("order_week")][, index := 1:.N]
sales_agg_week[, loess_week := fitted(loess(sales_per_week ~ index, span = 0.2))]
p1 <- sales_agg_week %>% plot_ly(x = ~order_week, y = ~sales_per_week) %>%
  add_lines(name = ~"sales_per_week") %>%
  add_lines(x = ~order_week, y = ~loess_week, name = ~"smoothed sales") %>%
  layout(title = "Sales per week")
p1

Monthly time series

Analyzing the monthly sales, we again see a peak around the previous observed time period and a drop at the end.

sales_daily[, order_month := tsibble::yearmonth(order_date)]
monthly_sales <- sales_daily[, .(sales_per_month = sum(sales_per_day), 
                               volume_per_month = sum(volume_per_day))
                             ,by = c("order_month", "product_category")]
Plot_Func(data = monthly_sales, x_col = "order_month",
          y_col = "sales_per_month", group_col = re_level,
          x_axis = "Month", y_axis = "Sales per Month", title = "Monthly Sales")
sales_agg_month <- monthly_sales[, .(sales_per_month = sum(sales_per_month), 
                             volume_per_month = sum(volume_per_month)), 
                                by = c("order_month")][, index := 1:.N]
sales_agg_month[, loess_month := fitted(loess(sales_per_month ~ index, span = 0.35))]
p1 <- sales_agg_month %>% plot_ly(x = ~order_month, y = ~sales_per_month) %>%
  add_lines(name = ~"sales_per_month") %>%
  add_lines(x = ~order_month, y = ~loess_month, name = ~"smoothed sales") %>%
  layout(title = "Sales per month")
p1

Forecasting

At this point we are going to extrapolate the time series several steps into the future. We are going to use the fable package and dplyr from now on. At first I create a tsibble, a tidy data structure which inherits from tibble, dplyr´s extension of a data.frame.

Time series forecasting is a complex field of research. I will focus on relatively simple non-seasonal ARIMA models. We will discuss forecasting for daily, weekly and monthly time series. Some series are simply to short to allow for accurate accessment of the seasonal parts. We begin with the aggregated series. Afterwards forecasting will be done on a product level for the respective frequencies.

The parameters for the ARIMA models are chosen automatically by the ARIMA function. Again, I assume that we do not have seasonal components. Furthermore I will not test the models using a test set or even cross validation. I do not recommend this procedure, but I simply test fable syntax here to get familiar with the package.

Daily

Here we create a tsibble. We define a key and index. The index is the time index, whereas key sets the grouping variable.

(daily_ts <- tsibble::as_tsibble(sales_daily, 
                                 index = order_date, 
                                 key = product_category)) 
## # A tsibble: 43,344 x 6 [1D]
## # Key:       product_category [72]
##    order_date product_category sales_per_day volume_per_day order_week
##    <date>     <fct>                    <dbl>          <int>     <week>
##  1 2017-01-05 agro_industry_a~             0              0   2017 W01
##  2 2017-01-06 agro_industry_a~             0              0   2017 W01
##  3 2017-01-07 agro_industry_a~             0              0   2017 W01
##  4 2017-01-08 agro_industry_a~             0              0   2017 W01
##  5 2017-01-09 agro_industry_a~             0              0   2017 W02
##  6 2017-01-10 agro_industry_a~             0              0   2017 W02
##  7 2017-01-11 agro_industry_a~             0              0   2017 W02
##  8 2017-01-12 agro_industry_a~             0              0   2017 W02
##  9 2017-01-13 agro_industry_a~             0              0   2017 W02
## 10 2017-01-14 agro_industry_a~             0              0   2017 W02
## # ... with 43,334 more rows, and 1 more variable: order_month <mth>
  1. Aggregated forecasts

We transform the sales_agg_day into a tsibble. The as_tsibble function transforms a data.table, which also has the class data.frame, into a tsibble object. The index argument is set to order_date.

sales_agg_ts <- sales_agg_day %>% 
  tsibble::as_tsibble(index = order_date)

We can easily train an ARIMA model by calling model and ARIMA. PDQ(0, 0, 0) sets the seasonal components to zero.

daily_model <- sales_agg_ts %>% 
  fabletools::model(fable::ARIMA(sales_per_day ~  PDQ(0, 0, 0)))

The models can now be used to generate forecasts. h = 7 sets the forecast horizon to seven days.

daily_model %>% forecast(h = 7) %>% 
  feasts::autoplot(sales_agg_ts) 
## `mutate_if()` ignored the following grouping variables:
## Column `index`

  1. Forecasts for product categories

Since not every product_category was sold from the beginning, I filter out the days where nothing was sold. This should only occur at the start of every time series per product_category. I search for the minimum order_day of every product_category while the sales are non-null. I save the result in look_up. Afterwards I perform a non-equi join.

look_up <- sales_daily[sales_per_day > 0, min(order_date), by = "product_category"]

(daily_ts <- sales_daily[look_up, on = .(product_category, order_date >= V1),
              .(x.order_date, product_category, sales_per_day, volume_per_day)] %>% 
                as_tibble() %>% 
                tsibble::as_tsibble(index = x.order_date, key = product_category))
## # A tsibble: 40,069 x 4 [1D]
## # Key:       product_category [72]
##    x.order_date product_category           sales_per_day volume_per_day
##    <date>       <fct>                              <dbl>          <int>
##  1 2017-01-23   agro_industry_and_commerce          44.0              2
##  2 2017-01-24   agro_industry_and_commerce           0                0
##  3 2017-01-25   agro_industry_and_commerce           0                0
##  4 2017-01-26   agro_industry_and_commerce           0                0
##  5 2017-01-27   agro_industry_and_commerce           0                0
##  6 2017-01-28   agro_industry_and_commerce           0                0
##  7 2017-01-29   agro_industry_and_commerce           0                0
##  8 2017-01-30   agro_industry_and_commerce           0                0
##  9 2017-01-31   agro_industry_and_commerce          22.0              1
## 10 2017-02-01   agro_industry_and_commerce           0                0
## # ... with 40,059 more rows
daily_models <- daily_ts %>% model(ARIMA(sales_per_day ~  PDQ(0, 0, 0)))
daily_models %>% forecast(h = 7)
## # A fable: 504 x 5 [1D]
## # Key:     product_category, .model [72]
##    product_category   .model       x.order_date sales_per_day .distribution
##    <fct>              <chr>        <date>               <dbl> <dist>       
##  1 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sales~ 2018-08-30           148.  N(148, 15978~
##  2 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sales~ 2018-08-31           145.  N(145, 16014~
##  3 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sales~ 2018-09-01           165.  N(165, 16045~
##  4 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sales~ 2018-09-02           134.  N(134, 16061~
##  5 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sales~ 2018-09-03           172.  N(172, 16640~
##  6 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sales~ 2018-09-04           172.  N(172, 16648~
##  7 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sales~ 2018-09-05           172.  N(172, 16656~
##  8 air_conditioning   ARIMA(sales~ 2018-08-30            90.8 N(91, 47638) 
##  9 air_conditioning   ARIMA(sales~ 2018-08-31            90.8 N(91, 47638) 
## 10 air_conditioning   ARIMA(sales~ 2018-09-01            90.8 N(91, 47638) 
## # ... with 494 more rows
daily_models %>% forecast(h = 7) %>% 
  filter(product_category == "health_beauty") %>% 
  autoplot(daily_ts)

Weekly

  1. Aggregated forecasts
sales_agg_week <- sales_agg_week %>% as_tibble() %>% 
  tsibble::as_tsibble(index = order_week)
weekly_model <- sales_agg_week %>% model(ARIMA(sales_per_week ~ PDQ(0, 0, 0)))
weekly_model %>% forecast(h = 12) %>% autoplot(sales_agg_week)
## `mutate_if()` ignored the following grouping variables:
## Column `index`

  1. Forecasts for product categories
look_up <- weekly_sales[sales_per_week > 0, min(order_week), by = "product_category"]

(weekly_ts <- weekly_sales[look_up, on = .(product_category, order_week >= V1),
              .(x.order_week, product_category, sales_per_week, volume_per_week)] %>% 
                as_tibble() %>% 
                mutate(x.order_week = tsibble::yearweek(x.order_week)) %>%
                tsibble::as_tsibble(index = x.order_week, key = product_category))
## # A tsibble: 5,795 x 4 [1W]
## # Key:       product_category [72]
##    x.order_week product_category           sales_per_week volume_per_week
##          <week> <fct>                               <dbl>           <int>
##  1     2017 W04 agro_industry_and_commerce           44.0               2
##  2     2017 W05 agro_industry_and_commerce           44.0               2
##  3     2017 W06 agro_industry_and_commerce          115.                2
##  4     2017 W07 agro_industry_and_commerce           66.0               3
##  5     2017 W08 agro_industry_and_commerce           22.0               1
##  6     2017 W09 agro_industry_and_commerce            0                 0
##  7     2017 W10 agro_industry_and_commerce            0                 0
##  8     2017 W11 agro_industry_and_commerce           60.0               1
##  9     2017 W12 agro_industry_and_commerce           22                 1
## 10     2017 W13 agro_industry_and_commerce            0                 0
## # ... with 5,785 more rows
weekly_models <- weekly_ts %>% model(ARIMA(sales_per_week ~  PDQ(0, 0, 0)))
weekly_models
## # A mable: 72 x 2
## # Key:     product_category [72]
##    product_category           `ARIMA(sales_per_week ~ PDQ(0, 0, 0))`
##    <fct>                      <model>                               
##  1 agro_industry_and_commerce <ARIMA(0,1,1)>                        
##  2 air_conditioning           <ARIMA(0,0,2) w/ mean>                
##  3 art                        <ARIMA(0,0,0) w/ mean>                
##  4 arts_and_craftmanship      <ARIMA(0,1,3)>                        
##  5 audio                      <ARIMA(0,1,1)>                        
##  6 auto                       <ARIMA(0,1,2)>                        
##  7 baby                       <ARIMA(0,1,1)>                        
##  8 bed_bath_table             <ARIMA(0,1,2)>                        
##  9 books_general_interest     <ARIMA(1,1,1)>                        
## 10 books_imported             <ARIMA(1,1,3)>                        
## # ... with 62 more rows
weekly_models %>% forecast(h = 8)
## # A fable: 576 x 5 [1W]
## # Key:     product_category, .model [72]
##    product_category   .model      x.order_week sales_per_week .distribution
##    <fct>              <chr>             <week>          <dbl> <dist>       
##  1 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sale~     2018 W36          1135. N(1135, 1781~
##  2 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sale~     2018 W37          1135. N(1135, 1808~
##  3 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sale~     2018 W38          1135. N(1135, 1835~
##  4 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sale~     2018 W39          1135. N(1135, 1862~
##  5 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sale~     2018 W40          1135. N(1135, 1888~
##  6 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sale~     2018 W41          1135. N(1135, 1915~
##  7 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sale~     2018 W42          1135. N(1135, 1942~
##  8 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sale~     2018 W43          1135. N(1135, 1969~
##  9 air_conditioning   ARIMA(sale~     2018 W36           611. N(611, 29228~
## 10 air_conditioning   ARIMA(sale~     2018 W37           766. N(766, 30051~
## # ... with 566 more rows
weekly_models %>% forecast(h = 8) %>% 
  filter(product_category == "health_beauty") %>% 
  autoplot(weekly_ts)

Monthly

  1. Aggregated Forecasts
(sales_agg_month <- sales_agg_month %>% as_tibble() %>% 
  tsibble::as_tsibble(index = order_month))
## # A tsibble: 20 x 5 [1M]
## # Groups:    @ index [20]
##    order_month sales_per_month volume_per_month index loess_month
##          <mth>           <dbl>            <int> <int>       <dbl>
##  1    2017 Jan         120098.              953     1     123525.
##  2    2017 Feb         244959.             1936     2     244906.
##  3    2017 Mrz         368341.             2975     3     339238.
##  4    2017 Apr         353843.             2660     4     407061.
##  5    2017 Mai         503159.             4106     5     445573.
##  6    2017 Jun         429917.             3571     6     467057.
##  7    2017 Jul         492287.             4493     7     485663.
##  8    2017 Aug         568246.             4882     8     564784.
##  9    2017 Sep         621416.             4815     9     597366.
## 10    2017 Okt         660180.             5300    10     755282.
## 11    2017 Nov        1003862.             8626    11     850675.
## 12    2017 Dez         742184.             6300    12     884968.
## 13    2018 Jan         945456.             8173    13     842021.
## 14    2018 Feb         837895.             7597    14     910822.
## 15    2018 Mrz         981051.             8195    15     942481.
## 16    2018 Apr         993593.             7957    16    1011612.
## 17    2018 Mai         992872.             7898    17     962793.
## 18    2018 Jun         863266.             7060    18     910238.
## 19    2018 Jul         878044.             7039    19     872042.
## 20    2018 Aug         848860.             7216    20     845810.
monthly_model <- sales_agg_month %>% model(ARIMA(sales_per_month ~   PDQ(0, 0, 0)))
monthly_model %>% forecast(h = 6) %>% autoplot(sales_agg_month)
## `mutate_if()` ignored the following grouping variables:
## Column `index`

  1. Forecasts for product categories
look_up <- monthly_sales[sales_per_month > 0, min(order_month), by = "product_category"]
(monthly_ts <-monthly_sales[look_up, on = .(product_category, order_month >= V1),
              .(x.order_month, product_category, sales_per_month, volume_per_month)] %>% 
                as_tibble() %>% 
                mutate(x.order_month = tsibble::yearmonth(x.order_month)) %>%
                tsibble::as_tsibble(index = x.order_month, key = product_category))
## # A tsibble: 1,355 x 4 [1M]
## # Key:       product_category [72]
##    x.order_month product_category          sales_per_month volume_per_month
##            <mth> <fct>                               <dbl>            <int>
##  1      2017 Jan agro_industry_and_commer~            66.0                3
##  2      2017 Feb agro_industry_and_commer~           225.                 7
##  3      2017 Mrz agro_industry_and_commer~            82.0                2
##  4      2017 Apr agro_industry_and_commer~             0                  0
##  5      2017 Mai agro_industry_and_commer~          1580.                 4
##  6      2017 Jun agro_industry_and_commer~          1390                  1
##  7      2017 Jul agro_industry_and_commer~          1180                  1
##  8      2017 Aug agro_industry_and_commer~            88                  4
##  9      2017 Sep agro_industry_and_commer~          1994.                 4
## 10      2017 Okt agro_industry_and_commer~          3350.                 5
## # ... with 1,345 more rows
monthly_models <- monthly_ts %>% model(ARIMA(sales_per_month ~  PDQ(0, 0, 0)))
monthly_models
## # A mable: 72 x 2
## # Key:     product_category [72]
##    product_category           `ARIMA(sales_per_month ~ PDQ(0, 0, 0))`
##    <fct>                      <model>                                
##  1 agro_industry_and_commerce <ARIMA(0,1,1)>                         
##  2 air_conditioning           <ARIMA(0,0,1) w/ mean>                 
##  3 art                        <ARIMA(0,0,0) w/ mean>                 
##  4 arts_and_craftmanship      <ARIMA(1,0,0) w/ mean>                 
##  5 audio                      <ARIMA(1,0,0) w/ mean>                 
##  6 auto                       <ARIMA(0,1,0)>                         
##  7 baby                       <ARIMA(0,1,0)>                         
##  8 bed_bath_table             <ARIMA(1,1,0)>                         
##  9 books_general_interest     <ARIMA(0,1,1)>                         
## 10 books_imported             <ARIMA(1,1,0)>                         
## # ... with 62 more rows

Forecasting for all product categories

monthly_models %>% forecast(h = 6)
## # A fable: 432 x 5 [1M]
## # Key:     product_category, .model [72]
##    product_category   .model    x.order_month sales_per_month .distribution
##    <fct>              <chr>             <mth>           <dbl> <dist>       
##  1 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sa~      2018 Sep           5418. N(5418, 9.9e~
##  2 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sa~      2018 Okt           5418. N(5418, 1.2e~
##  3 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sa~      2018 Nov           5418. N(5418, 1.4e~
##  4 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sa~      2018 Dez           5418. N(5418, 1.6e~
##  5 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sa~      2019 Jan           5418. N(5418, 1.9e~
##  6 agro_industry_and~ ARIMA(sa~      2019 Feb           5418. N(5418, 2.1e~
##  7 air_conditioning   ARIMA(sa~      2018 Sep           2129. N(2129, 1193~
##  8 air_conditioning   ARIMA(sa~      2018 Okt           2663. N(2663, 1494~
##  9 air_conditioning   ARIMA(sa~      2018 Nov           2663. N(2663, 1494~
## 10 air_conditioning   ARIMA(sa~      2018 Dez           2663. N(2663, 1494~
## # ... with 422 more rows

We can show an example for the forecast of the product_category health_beauty.

monthly_models %>% forecast(h = 6) %>% 
  filter(product_category == "health_beauty") %>% 
  autoplot(monthly_ts)

Models

Using the report function we can take a closer look on what parameters were chosen. Using the accuracy function we can assess the errors of the models on our training data.

# daily_model %>% report()
# daily_model %>% accuracy()
# weekly_model %>% report()
# weekly_model %>% accuracy()
# monthly_model %>% report()
# monthly_model %>% accuracy()

Reports of the models on product category level are not directly possible using daily_models %>% report(). You could analyze a specific model with

#daily_models %>% filter(product_category == "health_beauty") %>% report()

As the final step we plot the fitted values vs the observed sales.

# daily_model %>% augment() %>% ggplot() +
#   geom_line(aes(x = order_date, y = sales_per_day, col = "red")) + 
#   geom_point(aes(x = order_date, y = .fitted))
# weekly_model %>% augment() %>% ggplot() +
#   geom_line(aes(x = order_week, y = sales_per_week, col = "red")) + 
#   geom_point(aes(x = order_week, y = .fitted))
# monthly_model %>% augment() %>% ggplot() +
#   geom_line(aes(x = order_month, y = sales_per_month, col = "red")) + 
#   geom_point(aes(x = order_month, y = .fitted))

Summary

In this post we explored the fable package, mainly how we can utilize it to forecast multiple time series stored in a specific data structure (tsibble). The package is very straightforward to use. Though we only scratched the surface of this package and I am sure that I will come back to it for testing and cross-validating time series. Furthermore it would be interesting on how we can extend the model library of this package with self-defined algorithmns.

Links: - https://github.com/tidyverts/fable - https://otexts.com/fpp3/ - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ykiuj16P450

See you soon! Moritz
